Title: $\Bbb Z[i]/(a+bi)\cong \Bbb Z/(a^2+b^2)$ if $(a,b)=1$. Gaussian integer quotient rings.
Content: A very basic ring theory question, which I am not able to solve. How does one show that $\mathbb{Z}[i]/(3-i) \cong \mathbb{Z}/10\mathbb{Z}$. Extending the result: $\mathbb{Z}[i]/(a-ib) \cong \mathbb{Z}/(a^{2}+b^{2})\mathbb{Z}$, if $a,b$ are relatively prime. My attempt was to define a map, $\varphi:\mathbb{Z}[i] \to \mathbb{Z}/10\mathbb{Z}$ and show that the kernel is the ideal generated by $\langle{3-i\rangle}$. But I couldn't think of such a map. Anyhow, any ideas would be helpful.
AcceptedAnswer:
Define $$\phi: \mathbb{Z} \rightarrow \mathbb{Z}[i]/(3-i) \text{ where } \phi(z) = z + (3-i)\mathbb{Z}[i].$$ It follows simply that $\ker \phi = (3-i)\mathbb{Z}[i] \cap \mathbb{Z}$ .
So for any such $z \in \ker \phi$ , we have $z = (3-i)(a+bi)$ for some $a,b \in \mathbb{Z}$ . But $(3-i)(a+bi) \in \mathbb{Z}$ happens if and only if $3b-a=0$ .
So $$\begin{align*}
\ker \phi = (3-i)\mathbb{Z}[i] \cap \mathbb{Z} &= \{(3-i)(3b+bi)\mid b \in \mathbb{Z}\}\\
&= \{(9b + b) + i(3b-3b)\mid b \in \mathbb{Z}\}\\
&= \{10b\mid b \in \mathbb{Z}\}\\
&= 10\mathbb{Z}.
\end{align*}$$ To see $\phi$ is surjective, let $(a+bi) + (3-i)\mathbb{Z}[i] \in \mathbb{Z}[i]/(3-i)$ . Then $a+bi=a+3b-3b+bi=(a+3b)-b(3-i)$ , so $\phi(a+3b) = (a+bi) + (3-i)\mathbb{Z}[i]$ . Hence $\mathbb{Z}[i]/(3-i) \cong \mathbb{Z}/10\mathbb{Z}$ .
